questions.text: NO is synthesised from:
questions.solution: NO is formed by NO synthase, a Ca 2+ -activated enzyme found in the cytosol. NO synthase catalyzes the five-electron oxidation of an guanidino nitrogen in the side chain of arginine, yielding citrulline and NO

questions.text: Which of the following clotting factor in a patient on warfarin therapy, would have decreased gamma carboxyglutamate residue?
questions.solution: The coumarin drugs (eg, warfarin), which are used as anticoagulants, inhibit the vitamin K-dependent carboxylation of Glu to Gla residues in the amino-terminal regions of factors II, VII, IX, and X and also proteins C and S

questions.text: Identify the sleep wave marked (5th wave) in the EEG during sleep wake cycle
Identify the cells type marked in the cerebellum?
questions.solution: Purkinje Cells are the flask shaped present in the purkinje cell layer of the Cerebellum which exerts Negative Inhibitory action on the Deep Nuclei

questions.text: Water hammer pulse is seen in-
questions.solution:
Watson's water hammer pulse, also known as Corrigan's pulse or collapsing pulse, is the medical sign (seen in aortic regurgitation) which describes a pulse that is bounding and forceful, rapidly increasing and subsequently collapsing, as if it were the sound of a water hammer that was causing the pulse.


Option c) aortic stenosis: shows pulsus parvus etardus

Option d) left ventricular failure: shows pulsus alternans

questions.text: A 65 yr old lady presents with a vascular injury to the inferior frontal gyrus. Which functional area would mostly be affected?
questions.solution: At the inferior Frontal Gyrus, there is Broca's Area, which Helps, in the expressive speech With Brodmann Number 44.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female watching TV for long hours with hand over the head, she complains of tingling sensation all over her arm. Which type of nerve fiber is likely to be affected?
questions.solution:
Type A fibers are myelinated, larger diameter fibers that transmit motor signals, proprioception, and sensory signals such as sharp pain and temperature. In this case, tingling sensation is most likely caused by compression or irritation of the sensory nerve fibers, which are part of the Type A group (specifically Aβ or Aδ fibers, which are responsible for transmitting touch, proprioception, and some sensory sensations like tingling). These fibers are involved in the sensory pathways that can lead to sensations like tingling when the nerves are under pressure.

Incorrect Options:

  • Type B fibers: These fibers are myelinated, but they are involved in transmitting signals from the autonomic nervous system, such as those related to the regulation of internal organ functions (e.g., heart rate), not sensory sensations like tingling.
  • Type C fibers: These are unmyelinated fibers that carry slow pain, temperature sensations, and autonomic signals, typically involved in dull pain or long-term sensations, not tingling.
  • Sympathetic fibers: These fibers are part of the autonomic nervous system and are not involved in the transmission of sensory sensations like tingling.

Key Takeaway:

  • Type A fibers (specifically Aβ and Aδ) are involved in sensory functions such as touch and proprioception, and their compression can lead to tingling sensations.
  • Type B fibers and Type C fibers are less likely to be involved in this specific sensory symptom.
  • Sympathetic fibers are unrelated to sensory sensation

questions.text: A boy met with an motor bike accident. CT brain shows injury to posterior end of superior temporal gyrus. He is likely to suffer from?
questions.solution: Injury to the superior temporal Gyrus Brodmann number 22 Wernicke's area results in the Fluent Aphasia The person is very talkative and comprehension is lost

questions.text: The reflex in which there is inhibition of gastric emptying when there is acid or hypertonic solution in the duodenum
questions.solution:
Enterogastric Inhibition irritation of duodenal mucosa causes initiation of Enterogastric Reflex that delays gastric emptying.


Other Factors decreasing gastric Emptying are

  1. Duodenal Distension
  2. Irritation of Duodenal Mucosa
  3. Acidic chyme
  4. Hyperosmolar Chyme
  5. High Fat content of Chyme.

questions.text: In multiple sclerosis slow conduction of sensory and motor pathway is due to
questions.solution:
Autoimmune inflammation and demyelination of CNS (brain and spinal cord) with subsequent axonal damage. Most often affects females aged 20-40

Symptoms may exacerbate with increased body temperature (eg, hot bath, exercise). Relapsing and remitting is most common clinical course.

↑IgG level and myelin basic protein in CSF. Oligoclonal bands aid in diagnosis. MRI is gold standard. Periventricular plaques A (areas of oligodendrocyte loss and reactive gliosis). Multiple white matter lesions disseminated in space and time.

questions.text: In a Pattern baby with respiratory distress syndrome, which type of cell is deficient?
questions.solution:
Type 2 alveolar cells are responsible for producing surfactant, a substance that reduces surface tension in the lungs, preventing alveolar collapse and facilitating normal lung function. Respiratory distress syndrome (RDS) in newborns, especially in preterm infants, is due to the immature or insufficient production of surfactant. This leads to alveolar collapse, impaired gas exchange, and respiratory distress.

Incorrect Options:

  • Type 1 alveolar cell: These cells cover the majority of the alveolar surface and are involved in gas exchange. They are not responsible for surfactant production, which is the primary issue in RDS.
  • Alveolar capillary endothelial cells: These cells form the blood-air barrier and are important for gas exchange, but surfactant deficiency is not related to their function in RDS.
  • Bronchial mucosal epithelial cells: These cells line the bronchi and bronchioles and are involved in mucus production and airway protection. They are not the source of surfactant and are not deficient in RDS.

Key Takeaways:

  • Type 2 alveolar cells produce surfactant, which is deficient in respiratory distress syndrome.
  • RDS is common in preterm infants, where immature lungs cannot produce enough surfactant, leading to alveolar collapse and breathing difficulties.
  • Treatment options include surfactant replacement therapy and respiratory support.

questions.text: Fertilization most commonly takes place at:
questions.solution: Ampulla is the site for fertilization

questions.text: Blood stored in citrate phosphate dextrose is better for hypoxia patients, than acid citrate dextrose because:
questions.solution: 2-3 bisphosphoglycerate binds to beta chain of the hemoglobin, this is required in Rbcs to release oxygen from hemoglobin at the tissue leaving Right Shift therefore CPD is preferred over ACD In hypoxic patient so that 2-3BPG fall less and Oxygen delivery to tissues is better.

questions.text: A 50yr old man presents with paresthesia, Hb- 6.8 g/dl. Peripheral smear shows macrocytes and neutrophils with hyper segmented nuclei. Endoscopy reveals atrophic gastritis. Which of the deficiency is most likely?
questions.solution:
Pernicious Anemia a Type 2 Hypersensitivity in which Abs are formed against Intrinsic Factor thus Inhibits the Binding of intrinsic factor+B12

  • Pernicious anemia commonly accompanies gastric atrophy and achlorhydria. Normal gastric secretions contain a glycoprotein called intrinsic factor, secreted by the same parietal cells that secrete hydrochloric acid.
  • Intrinsic factor must be present for adequate absorption of vitamin B 12 from the ileum. That is, intrinsic factor combines with vitamin B12 in the stomach and protects it from being digested and destroyed as it passes into the small intestine.
  • Then, when the intrinsic factor-vitamin B 12 complex reaches the terminal ileum, the intrinsic factor binds with receptors on the ileal epithelial surface, which in turn makes it possible for the vitamin B 12 to be absorbed.
  • In the absence of intrinsic factor, only about 1/50th of the vitamin B 12 is absorbed. In addition, without intrinsic factor, an adequate amount of vitamin B 12 is not made available from the foods to cause young, newly forming red blood cells to mature in the bone marrow. The result is pernicious anemia

choices.text: Bulging of tricuspid valve during the isovolumetric contraction phase

questions.text: C wave in JVP is due to:
questions.solution:
Jugular venous pulse (JVP):


  • a wave-atrial contraction. Prominent in AV dissociation (cannon a wave) and tricuspid stenosis, absent in atrial fibrillation.
  • c wave-RV contraction (closed tricuspid valve bulging into atrium).
  • x descent-atrial relaxation and downward displacement of closed tricuspid valve during rapid ventricular ejection phase. Reduced or absent in tricuspid regurgitation and right HF because pressure gradients are reduced.
  • v wave-↑RA pressure due to ↑volume against closed tricuspid valve.
  • y descent-RA emptying into RV. Prominent in constrictive pericarditis, absent in cardiac tamponade.

questions.text: Ph-7.2, HCO3- 10Meq/L, Pco2- 30mmHg, this exemplifies which of the following disorder
questions.solution:
In the given scenario Ph is <7.35 , so its ACIDOSIS

Pco2- 30mmHg (normally around 40mmHg), so its reduced due to hyperventilation (compensatory mechanism)

HCO3- 10Meq/L (normally around 24mmHg), so its reduced indicating metabolic acidosis

choices.text: Short telomere with damaged DNA and loss of helicase

questions.text: A 42 yr old patient with symptoms of premature aging and is diagnosed as Werner syndrome. The most likely mechanism?
questions.solution:
Werner syndrome is characterized by the dramatic, rapid appearance of features associated with normal aging. Individuals with this disorder typically grow and develop normally until they reach puberty

Werner syndrome is characterised by the defective DNA Helicase Enzym, which causes short telomere and damage DNA

questions.text: A 55yr old male presents with tachypnea and mental confusion. Blood glucose 350mg/dl, Ph=7.0. What is the most likely acid base disorder?
questions.solution:
In Diabetic Ketoacidosis there is an Increased Production of Acetoacetic acid and beta hydroxy Butyric Acid which leads to an increase in plasma concentration of Hydrogen ions leading to Metabolic Acidosis.

This is compensated by hyperventilation i.e kussmall's breathing

questions.solution: Heparan Sulphate is one of Glycosaminoglycan present on cell surfaces and contains negatively charged repels negative charge molecules and thus is important in Glomerular filtration and has role in retinal cells attachments.

questions.text: When VA/Q is infinity, it means
questions.solution:
V/Q ratio normal value is 0.8

VA/Q = infinity means perfusion to lungs is zero, that is blood supply to that area is hindered making it a wasted ventilation in those alveoli.

This may be due to pulmonary embolism causing Increased Physiological Dead Space.

Dead Space is an area in which air never reaches the Gas exchange area.

Physiological/Total Dead Space=Anatomical dead Space + alveolar dead space.

questions.text: In preterm baby with respiratory distress syndrome which of the following lipid would be deficient?
questions.solution: Phospholipid Dipalmitoyl Phosphatidyl Choline acts as surfactant and Acts to reduce surface tension, which helps in proper expansion of Lungs. In preterm babies, it is deficient. So preterm babies are prone for respiratory distress syndrome

questions.text: Which of the following binds to tyrosine kinase receptor
questions.solution:
Hormones that Use Receptor Tyrosine Kinase Signalling.

  1. Growth Hormone
  2. Insulin
  3. Leptin
  4. Prolactin
  5. Growth Factors

questions.text: Serum prolactin levels are highest?
questions.solution:
• In humans, prolactin secretion is increased by exercise, surgical and psychological stresses, and stimulation of the nipple.
  • The plasma prolactin level rises during sleep, the rise starting after the onset of sleep and persisting through out the sleep period.
  • Secretion is increased during pregnancy, reaching a peak at the time of parturition. After delivery, the plasma concentration falls to nonpregnant levels in about 8 days.
  • Suckling produces a prompt increase in secretion, but the magnitude of this rise gradually declines after a woman has been nursing for more than 3 months. With prolonged lactation, milk secretion occurs with prolactin levels that are in the normal range.

choices.text: Normal person after wakening in morning

questions.text: In which of the following conditions would the cortisol level be highest?
questions.solution: The Secretion of Cortisol along with ACTH are high in early Morning.

questions.text: Impaired function of aquaporin results in:
questions.solution:
• normal or elevated levels of ADH are present but the renal tubular segments cannot respond appropriately. This condition is referred to as nephrogenic diabetes insipidus because the abnormality resides in the kidneys.
  • This abnormality can be due to failure of the countercurrent mechanism to form a hyperosmotic renal medullary interstitium or failure of the distal and collecting tubules and collecting ducts to respond to ADH (due to impaired function/defect in aquaporin-2 receptor or V2 receptor.
  • In either case, large volumes of dilute urine are formed, which causes dehydration unless fluid intake is increased by the same amount as urine volume is increased.

questions.text: Vitamin B12 is found in?
questions.solution:
Vit B12 is mainly obtained from Non Vegetarian Diet.

Sources of Vit B12 are Salmon fish, Egg, Milk, beef, Chicken, tuna etc

questions.text: A young man met with motor bike accident and head injury to ileum and jejunum. Therefore the entire ileum and partial jejunum was resected. Which of the following would the patient suffer from?
questions.solution:
Due to Resection of the Jejunum and Ileum Mainly the Deficiency of the Substance which are absorbed from them respectively will occur.

Nutrients absorbed from Ileum are Mainly Vit B12, Magnesium, Bile salts etc

Nutrients absorbed from Jejunum are Mainly All Major Nutrients, Water, Long Chain Fatty Acids.
